On Tuesday 20 May 2003 15:16, Walden Mathews wrote:
> > > I would hazard an
> > > intuitive guess that a lack of even a semi-formal set of conventions
> > > for declaratively describing / documenting resource models is one of
> > > the main sources of friction that we (the REST community) experience in
> > > trying to communicate with the unenlightened. ;-)
> >
> > I agree. I think a great deal of the friction is based on
> > illogical arguments. With a more rigorous model, these arguments
> > could be more easily and decisively refuted.
>
> Which arguments?

For example, I have repeatedly seen the claim that REST may be
good for simple applications, but that larger applications are
better done using the SOAP-based web-services machinery.

You and Mark Baker were just involved in a go-round of this
permathread on the www-ws-arch list. Mark responded to the
challenge with a simple sketch of how additional functionality
could be added to a purchase order application. I have seen
similar answers in the past. I suspect the critics will remain
unsatisfied with this response and the permathread will continue
another day.

With a rigorous model, it could be more convincingly shown that a
REST model is at least as expressive as a SOAP-based model. For
example, in the web-calculus spec, I show that the web-calculus
encompases the functionality of DEM. See:

http://www.waterken.com/dev/Web/Calculus/#Document_Exchange_Model_(DEM)

Hopefully, people will find such an analytic answer more
convincing.

Tyler
